As we can see, we can divide the side in the proportion 1:1:1, and it will look like this. There are 4 triangles, that are the half of the rectangle where they are. And there's also a rectangle in the middle, whose area is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{1}{3}l \times \frac{1}{3}l = \frac{1}{9} A_{ABCD}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" And the triangles are the other "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{8}{9}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", so it's "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{1}{2} \times \frac{8}{9} + \frac {1}{9} = \frac{5}{9}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/brioche/uploads/FdaRfYoyaS-b200409.png?width=400"}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let the height and breadth of rectangle "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"ABCD"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" be "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3b"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" respectively. Then the area of quadrilateral "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"PQSR"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\begin{aligned} [PQRS] & = [ABCD] - [APS] - [BPQ] - [CQR] - [DRS]
\\ & = (3a)(3b) - \frac 12(2a)b - \frac 12a(2b) - \frac 12(2a)b - \frac 12a(2b)
\\ & = 9ab - ab - ab -ab - ab = 5ab
\\ \implies \frac {[PQRS]}{[ABCD]} & = \boxed{\frac 59}\end{aligned} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 12,12,12,will this continue?

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We can find the solution of x^4 + y^4 + z^4  by the following steps:
       (x+y+z)^2    = x^2 + y^2 + z^2 + 2(xy+xz+yz),    so that     (xy+xz+yz) = 66,
    (x+y+z)^3   = x^3 + y^3 + z^3 + 3(xy+xz+yz) (x+y+z) – 3xyx ,    then we find :xyz = 220,
    (xy+xz+yz)^2    = (xy)^2 + (xz)^2 + (yz)^2 + 2xyz(x+y+z),   then we can find    (xy)^2 + (xz)^2 + (yz)^2 = - 924,
    (x^2 + y^2 + z^2)^2 =  x^4 + y^4 + z^4 + 2((xy)^2 + (xz)^2 + (yz)^2),   finally we can find x^4 + y^4 + z^4 = 1992"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            o can we find the values of x, y and z that satisfy the system of equations? Just curious how a sum of three numbers can equal the sum of their squares. I can see it with cubes as numbers can turn out negative, but squares? (0 and 1 are obviously not the solution here)

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"P_n = x^n + y^n+z^n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is a positive integer, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"S_1=x+y+z=12"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"S_2 = xy + yz+zx"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"S_3 = xyz"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".  Given "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"P_1=P_2=P_3=12"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", we need to find "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"P_4 = x^4+y^4+z^4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". By Newton's sums or Newton's identities, we have:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\begin{aligned} P_1 & = S_1 = 12
\\ P_2 & = S_1P_1 - 2S_2 = 12(12) -2S_2 = 12 & \small \color{#3D99F6} \implies S_2 = 66
\\ P_3 & = S_1P_2 - S_2P_1 + 3S_3 = 12(12) -66(12) + 3S_3 = 12 & \small \color{#3D99F6} \implies S_3 = 220
\\ P_4 & = S_1P_3 - S_2P_2 + S_3P_1 = 12(12) -66(12) + 220(12) = \boxed{1992} 
\end{aligned} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

"}]},{"type":"text","text":" "}]}

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            My mistake was in assuming the variables were positive.  I did the same calculation to get xyz = 220 and then erroneously concluded that a sum of 12 made this impossible!

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            In fact, the variables aren't even real numbers in this problem. If they were, we would have from x+y+z=12 that at least one of the numbers x,y and z is 4 or greater. By symmetry, we can assume x>=4 which means x^2>=16. Assuming y and z are real, we have x^2+y^2+z^2>=16 which contradicts the group of equations given. It only has complex solutions.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Can you please explain how you got it??

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"My workings isn't as short or as elegant as those that had already posted, but this was how I worked it out."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Using Vieta's formulas, where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x, y, z"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are the roots of a cubic polynomial:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\sum x = 12 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(x + y +z)^2 = x^2 + y^2 + z^2 + 2\sum xy \implies \sum xy = 66 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"S_n = x^n + y^n + z^n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":":"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Then "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"S_3 - 12S_2+66S_1 - 3c = 0 \implies c = 220"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So the equation is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"w^3 - 12w^2 + 66w - 220 = 0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Now we can solve for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"S_4 = x^4 + y^4 + z^4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", by substituting the given equations in the question."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"S_4 - 12S_3 + 66S_2 - 220S_1 = 0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"S_4 = 12(12) - 66(12) + 220(12) = 1992"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"144 = (x + y + z)^2 = x^2 + y^2 + z^2 + 2(xy + xz + yz) = 12 + 2(xy + xz + yz) \implies \boxed{xy + xz + yz = 66}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1728 = (x + y + z)^3 = x^3 + y^3 + z^3 + 3x^2y + 3xy^2 + 3x^2z + 6xyz + 3y^2z + 3xz^2 + 3yz^2 = "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x^3 + y^3 + z^3 + 3(x + y + z)(xy + xz + yz) - 3xyz = 12 + 2376 - 3xyz = 2388 - 3xyz \implies \boxed{xyz = 220}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(20736 = (x + y + z)^4 = x^4 + y^4 + z^4 + (4x^3y + 4xy^3 + 4x^3z + 4y^3z + 4xz^3 + 4yz^3) + "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(6x^2y^2 + 12x^2yz + 12xy^2z + 6x^2z^2 + 12xyz^2 + 6y^2z^2)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":""}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":""}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"6(xy + xz + yz)^2 =6x^2y^2 + 12x^2yz + 12xy^2z + 6x^2z^2 + 12xyz^2 + 6y^2z^2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"and,"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4(x^2 + y^2 + z^2)(xy + xz + yz) = 4x^3y + 4xy^3 + 4x^3z + 4y^3z + 4xz^3 + 4yz^3 + 4(xyz)(x + y + z) \implies"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4x^3y + 4xy^3 + 4x^3z + 4y^3z + 4xz^3 + 4yz^3 =  4(x^2 + y^2 + z^2)(xy + xz + yz) -  4(xyz)(x + y + z)  "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\implies (x + y + z)^4 = 20736 = x^4 + y^4 + z^4 + 6(66^2) + 4(12)(66) - 4(220)(12) = x^4 + y^4 + z^4 + 18744 \implies "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\boxed{x^4 + y^4 + z^4 = 1992}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            If you meant whether we can find the individual values of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x,y,z"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" satisfying this system of equations, then yes!"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

Can you proceed from here?

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Your solution is slightly incorrect.
If you note "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"P_1 P_2^2 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is of degree 5 and the rest of the components are of degree 4. It should also be a "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{P_1^2 P_2}{2} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"horizontalRule"},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Letting "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"-b=x+y+z, c=xy+yz+zx, -d=xyz"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"From Newton's identities we have:
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"P_4 = -b P_3 -c P_2 -d P_1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"
We can see that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b = -P_1, c = \frac{P_1^2-P_2}{2}, d = -\frac{P_1^3+2P_3-3P_1 P_2}{6}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"P_4 = P_1 P_3 - (\frac{P_1^2-P_2}{2}) P_2 +(\frac{P_1^3+2P_3-3P_1 P_2}{6})P_1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"P_4 = \frac{4P_1 P_3}{3} - P_1^2 P_2 +\frac{P_1^4}{6}+\frac{P_2^2}{2} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"For example , take "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x=y=z=0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            This is very odd because this implies x+y+z = x^2+y^2+z^2 = x^3+y^3+z^3"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x^2+x^3+y^2+y^3+z^2+z^3 = 24 = 2(x^2+y^2+z^2)
x^2(x+1) + y^2(y+1) + z^2(z+1) = 2x^2+2y^2+2z^2
which implies:
x+1 = 2
y+1 = 2
z+1 = 2
so all of them are equal to 1. 
But they're obviously not all equal to 1. Whatever they are seem to break associative and communative properties. 
What gives?

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            It is more instructive to discover the relevant relations yourself. Here is how I solved it, which is a bit more direct. "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(x+y+z)^2 = x^2+y^+z^2+2(xy+yz+zx)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" implies "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"xy+yz+zx=(12^2-12)/2=66"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". And "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(x+y+z)^4=4(x^3+y^3+z^3)(x+y+z)-3(x^4+y^4+z^4)+6(xy+yz+zx)^2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" implies "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x^4+y^4+z^4=(4\times12^2+6\times66^2-12^4)/3=1992"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"This way, you don't need "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"xyz"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"How to find this? Observe that the given equations involve fully symmetric polynomials (whose value does not change for any permutation if the three variables). Adding and multiplying such symmetric polynomials again yields symmetric polynomials. Now play with powers of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x+y+z)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Is is, factorization that's what?

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}
